customData.content: 77-year-old asymptomatic man with abnormal shadow in the right middle lung field on radiograph. 2.5-pack-year smoking history. History of prostate cancer surgery at 61 years old and inguinal hernia surgery at 75 years old. Blood pressure, 117/53 mmHg; pulse rate, 59 beats/min; body temperature, 35.8°C; percutaneous oxygen saturation, 98%.

Neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes were non-palpable. Tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen, cytokeratin 19 fragment, pro-gastrin-releasing peptide, prostate-specific antigen) were normal. Chest radiography revealed an ill-defined patchy shadow, 20 mm in size, in the right middle lung field. CT revealed a 20 mm subpleural ground-glass opacity with pleural indentation and spiculation in the superior segment of the right lower lobe (S6) area.

imaging.finding: ill-defined patchy shadow, 20 mm in size, in the right middle lung field
20 mm subpleural ground-glass opacity with pleural indentation and spiculation in the superior segment of the right lower lobe (S6) area

customData.content: FDG-PET: FDG uptake (SUVmax=2.0) in the nodular shadow in the right S6. Abnormal FDG accumulation (SUVmax=approximately 6.0) in the bilateral ribs, lumbar vertebrae, bilateral femurs, and left ilium. No FDG accumulation in regional lymph nodes. MRI: No intracranial metastases. Enhancements in the parietal bone, left temporal bone, and cervical spine, suggestive of bone marrow reversion.

imaging.finding: FDG uptake (SUVmax=2.0) in the nodular shadow in the right S6
Abnormal FDG accumulation (SUVmax=approximately 6.0) in the bilateral ribs
Abnormal FDG accumulation (SUVmax=approximately 6.0) in the lumbar vertebrae
Abnormal FDG accumulation (SUVmax=approximately 6.0) in the bilateral femurs
Abnormal FDG accumulation (SUVmax=approximately 6.0) in the left ilium
No FDG accumulation in regional lymph nodes
Enhancements in the parietal bone, suggestive of bone marrow reversion
Enhancements in the left temporal bone, suggestive of bone marrow reversion
Enhancements in the cervical spine, suggestive of bone marrow reversion

customData.content: CT-guided percutaneous biopsy of the lung nodule: Fibrosis of the alveolar tissue and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with an acinar pattern within the fibrosis.

imaging.finding: Fibrosis of the alveolar tissue and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with an acinar pattern within the fibrosis

procedures.name: Biopsy
procedures.outcome: Fibrosis of the alveolar tissue and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with an acinar pattern within the fibrosis

customData.content: Lung adenocarcinoma [positive for an epidermal growth factor receptor mutation (L858R)]. Clinical stage IVB (cT1bN0M1c) with multiple bone metastases. MRI of the pelvic cavity: lesions diffusely spread over the lumbar spine, pelvis, and femur with a high signal intensity on T2-weighted, short TI inversion recovery, and diffusion-weighted imaging and a low signal intensity on T1-weighted phase contrast imaging, suggesting the possibility of re-conversion to the red marrow.

imaging.finding: lesions diffusely spread over the lumbar spine, pelvis, and femur with a high signal intensity on T2-weighted, short TI inversion recovery, and diffusion-weighted imaging and a low signal intensity on T1-weighted phase contrast imaging, suggesting the possibility of re-conversion to the red marrow.

customData.content: Areas in the red bone marrow had a high SUVmax. CT-guided biopsy of the left iliac bone: infiltrated with small atypical lymphocyte-like cells (CD5-positive, CD20-positive, CD43-positive, CD3-negative, CD10-negative, CD33-negative, and cyclin D1-negative) along the bone trabeculae without lung cancer metastases, leading to a diagnosis of a low-grade B-cell lymphoma. Bone marrow examination: B-cell clusters in some areas, CD20 positivity, and CD5 positivity, consistent with low-grade B-cell lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL).

Lung cancer clinical stage: cT1bN0M0, stage IA2. MRI of the pelvic cavity: diffuse high-signal lesions in the lumbar spine, pelvis, and femur on T1-weighted in-phase images and diffusion-weighted images; these lesions have a low signal on T1-weighted out-of-phase images. FDG-PET/CT: uptake of FDG in the left ilium. CT-guided percutaneous needle biopsy of the left iliac bone.

imaging.finding: diffuse high-signal lesions in the lumbar spine, pelvis, and femur on T1-weighted in-phase images and diffusion-weighted images; these lesions have a low signal on T1-weighted out-of-phase images
imaging.impression: diffuse high-signal lesions in the lumbar spine, pelvis, and femur

imaging.finding: uptake of FDG in the left ilium
imaging.impression: uptake of FDG in the left ilium

procedures.name: biopsy of the left iliac bone

customData.Immunohistochemistry: tumor cells positive for CD20 and CD5 and negative for CD3

data.content: Initial radiographic abnormality in right middle lung field prompts further investigation with tumor markers and chest CT.
Further imaging with FDG-PET and MRI to investigate lung lesion and potential metastases.
CT-guided biopsy performed on lung nodule to determine pathology.
Diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with EGFR mutation and bone metastases, leading to stage IVB lung cancer.
Further investigation of bone lesions reveals a second primary malignancy: low-grade B-cell lymphoma/CLL/SLL.
Lung cancer restaged to IA2, further imaging of pelvic cavity and biopsy of left iliac bone.
Iliac biopsy confirms infiltration of small tumor cells positive for CD20 and CD5 and negative for CD3.
